message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Distributed Games with a Central Decision Maker
Paper Abstract: We study distributed games played on non-deterministic asynchronous automata which feature a central decision maker process that participates in all key decision making tasks. In these partial-information games, processes use their causal past to respond to scheduling choices made by the scheduler and cooperatively strategize as a team to achieve the winning objective. We show that the problem of deciding the existence of a distributed winning strategy is efficiently solvable for global safety and local parity objectives. We provide algorithmic solutions that match their computational hardness. We formulate the notion of a finite-state distributed strategy which allows to quantify its distributed memory requirements. For the aforementioned objectives, we establish that finite-state distributed winning strategies always exist. In fact, we provide novel constructions of such winning strategies which are shown to have almost optimal amount of distributed memory. We also show that a natural extension of the model with two decision making processes is undecidable.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Safety properties"

Links: [{"title":"Safety and liveness properties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_property"},{"title":"Linear time property - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_time_property"},{"title":"Hyperproperty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperproperty"},{"title":"Asbestos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asbestos"},{"title":"Kevlar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevlar"}]

I've performed a web search for "Safety properties" and found results primarily related to computer science concepts. Here are the main findings:

## Safety Properties in Computer Science

Safety properties are formulations of computer program execution—particularly for concurrent and distributed systems—that express the concept "bad things don't happen". A safety property proscribes discrete bad things from occurring during an execution and thus characterizes what is permitted by stating what is prohibited.

## Relationship to Other Properties

Safety properties and liveness properties together form a complete decomposition, where all properties of an execution are a conjunction of safety and liveness properties. Example safety properties include "the vending machine does not dispense a drink until money has been entered".

## Historical Context

Leslie Lamport used the terms safety property and liveness property in his 1977 paper on proving the correctness of multiprocess (concurrent) programs.

The search results indicate that "safety properties" is primarily a technical term in computer science used for formal verification and system correctness analysis. If you were looking for a different meaning of "safety properties," please let me know and I can search for more specific information.

Links: [{"title":"Distributed computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing"},{"title":"Distributed Computing Environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Computing_Environment"},{"title":"Distributed networking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_networking"},{"title":"Advances in Distributed Computing and Artificial Intelligence Journal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Distributed_Computing_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Journal"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Grid computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grid_computing"},{"title":"Edge computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_computing"},{"title":"Parallel computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_computing"},{"title":"Cloud computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing"},{"title":"Cambridge Distributed Computing System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambridge_Distributed_Computing_System"}]

## Distributed Computing Search Results

I found comprehensive information about distributed computing. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Basics

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers.(no content)In distributed computing, a problem is divided into many tasks, each of which is solved by one or more computers, which communicate with each other via message passing.

### Key Characteristics

The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal. However, three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components.

### Advantages and Trade-offs

A well-designed distributed system is more scalable, more durable, more changeable, and more fine-tuned than a monolithic application deployed on a single machine. On the other hand, distributed systems cost more than monolithic architectures, primarily due to increased needs for additional hardware, servers, gateways, firewalls, new subnets, proxies, and so on.

### Related Concepts

Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications. Related technologies include edge computing, grid computing, cloud computing, and fog computing.

Links: [{"title":"Finite-state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine"},{"title":"Deterministic acyclic finite state automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_acyclic_finite_state_automaton"},{"title":"Aperiodic finite-state automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aperiodic_finite_state_automaton"},{"title":"Deterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Generalized nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Levenshtein automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_automaton"},{"title":"Automata-based programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata-based_programming"},{"title":"Büchi automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%BCchi_automaton"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about finite state automata:

## Overview

A finite-state automaton (FSA), also called a finite-state machine (FSM), is a mathematical model of computation.(no content)It is an abstract machine that can be in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time.

## Key Characteristics

A finite automaton has a start state (denoted graphically by an arrow coming in from nowhere) where computations begin, and a set of accept states (denoted graphically by a double circle) which help define when a computation is successful.

## Types of Finite Automata

There are two main categories:

1. **Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA)**: In a deterministic automaton, every state has exactly one transition for each possible input.

2. **Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFA)**: In a non-deterministic automaton, an input can lead to one, more than one, or no transition for a given state.(no content)Each NFA can be translated to an equivalent DFA using the subset construction algorithm.

## Applications

A DFA is often implemented in hardware and software for solving various specific problems such as lexical analysis and pattern matching. Additionally, NFAs are used in the implementation of regular expressions through Thompson's construction algorithm.

Links: [{"title":"Parity game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_game"},{"title":"Parity (sports) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_(sports)"},{"title":"Talk:Parity game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Parity_game"},{"title":"Parity (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Oliver Friedmann - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oliver_Friedmann"},{"title":"Mean payoff game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_payoff_game"},{"title":"Category:Parity (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Parity_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity"},{"title":"Thuuz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thuuz"},{"title":"Parity of zero - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_of_zero"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about parity games:

## What is a Parity Game?

A parity game is played on a colored directed graph, where each node has been colored by a priority – one of (usually) finitely many natural numbers. Two players, 0 and 1, move a (single, shared) token along the edges of the graph.(no content)The owner of the node that the token falls on selects the next edge to follow.

## Key Characteristics

Parity games are history-free determined, which means that if a player has a winning strategy then that player has a winning strategy that depends only on the current board position, and not on the history of the play.(no content)Solving a parity game played on a finite graph means deciding, for a given starting position, which of the two players has a winning strategy.

## Computational Complexity

Links: [{"title":"Nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Generalized nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_nondeterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Deterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Two-way finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-way_nondeterministic_finite_automaton?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Deterministic automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_automaton"},{"title":"Tagged Deterministic Finite Automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagged_Deterministic_Finite_Automaton"},{"title":"Deterministic acyclic finite state automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_acyclic_finite_state_automaton"},{"title":"Deterministic pushdown automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_pushdown_automaton"},{"title":"Unambiguous finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unambiguous_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Talk:Nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Nondeterministic_finite_automaton"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about non-deterministic automata:

## Definition

A nondeterministic finite automaton (NFA), or nondeterministic finite-state machine, does not need to obey the restrictions that each transition is uniquely determined by its source state and input symbol.

## Key Characteristics

For each input symbol, the NFA transitions to a new state until all input symbols have been consumed. In each step, the automaton nondeterministically "chooses" one of the applicable transitions. If there exists at least one "lucky run", some sequence of choices leading to an accepting state after completely consuming the input, it is accepted.

## Relationship to Deterministic Finite Automata

For each NFA, there is a DFA such that it recognizes the same formal language. The DFA can be constructed using the powerset construction. However, if the NFA has n states, the resulting DFA may have up to 2^n states, which sometimes makes the construction impractical for large NFAs.

## Language Recognition

Like DFAs, NFAs only recognize regular languages.

## History

NFAs were introduced in 1959 by Michael O. Rabin and Dana Scott, who also showed their equivalence to DFAs.

## Practical Applications

NFAs are used in the implementation of regular expressions: Thompson's construction is an algorithm for compiling a regular expression to an NFA.

## Extensions

NFAs have been generalized in multiple ways, e.g., nondeterministic finite automata with ε-moves, finite-state transducers, pushdown automata, alternating automata, ω-automata, and probabilistic automata.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Focal point (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_point_(game_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Game theory":

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## History

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)Von Neumann's work was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

John Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.(no content)A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats). Cooperative games are often analyzed through the framework of cooperative game theory, which focuses on predicting which coalitions will form, the joint actions that groups take, and the resulting collective payoffs.

## Recognition

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020.

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## History

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)Von Neumann's work was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

John Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.(no content)A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats). Cooperative games are often analyzed through the framework of cooperative game theory, which focuses on predicting which coalitions will form, the joint actions that groups take, and the resulting collective payoffs.

## Recognition

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020.

Here's an overview of the key information about automata theory from the web search results:

### Definition and Scope

Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them.(no content)It is a theory in theoretical computer science with close connections to cognitive science and mathematical logic.

### Etymology

The word automata comes from the Greek word αὐτόματος, which means "self-acting, self-willed, self-moving".

### Key Concepts

An automaton (automata in plural) is an abstract self-propelled computing device which follows a predetermined sequence of operations automatically.(no content)Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory. In this context, automata are used as finite representations of formal languages that may be infinite.

### Applications and Importance

Automata play a major role in the theory of computation, compiler construction, artificial intelligence, parsing and formal verification.

### Historical Development

The theory of abstract automata was developed in the mid-20th century in connection with finite automata.(no content)1956 saw the publication of Automata Studies, which collected work by scientists including Claude Shannon, W. Ross Ashby, John von Neumann, Marvin Minsky, Edward F. Moore, and Stephen Cole Kleene. With the publication of this volume, "automata theory emerged as a relatively autonomous discipline".

Web search results for query: "Partial information game"

Links: [{"title":"Complete information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_information"},{"title":"Perfect information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_information"},{"title":"Bayesian game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_game"},{"title":"Linear partial information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_partial_information"},{"title":"Impartial game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impartial_game"},{"title":"Incomplete information network game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_information_network_game"},{"title":"Tabletop game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabletop_game"},{"title":"Signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_games"},{"title":"Information set (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_set_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Extensive-form game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extensive-form_game"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about "partial information games":

## Definition

Games in which state uncertainty plays a role are referred to as partial or imperfect information games as opposed to full or perfect information games.

## Related Concepts

The search results reveal that partial information games are closely related to several game theory concepts:

**Incomplete Information**: In a game with incomplete information, players do not possess full information about other players, and some players possess private information, a fact that the others should take into account when forming expectations about how those players will behave.

**Bayesian Games**: A Bayesian game is a strategic decision-making model which assumes players have incomplete information, where players may hold private information relevant to the game, meaning that the payoffs are not common knowledge.

## Examples

Examples of games with imperfect but complete information are card games, where each player's cards are hidden from other players but objectives are known, as in contract bridge and poker.

The concept is fundamental to understanding strategic games where players must make decisions without full knowledge of the game state or other players' characteristics.

I found information about "distributed games" from the web search results. Here are the key findings:

## Game Distribution

The search results primarily relate to **game distribution** in the video game industry:

Digital distribution in the video game industry is the process of delivering video game content as digital information, without the exchange or purchase of new physical media such as ROM cartridges, magnetic storage, optical discs and flash memory cards.(no content)Digital distribution of video games is becoming increasingly common, with major publishers and retailers paying more attention to digital sales, including Steam, PlayStation Store, Amazon.com, GAME, GameStop, Xbox Live Marketplace, and others.

## Game Theory & Distributed Computing

The results also include references to games in academic contexts:

- **Distributed Algorithmic Mechanism Design (DAMD)**: This is an extension of algorithmic mechanism design where the algorithm is computed in a distributed manner rather than by a central authority.

- **Potential Games**: Academic work on game theory concepts applied to distributed systems and decentralized algorithms.

- **Massively Multiplayer Online Games**: Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

Could you clarify which aspect of "distributed games" you're most interested in—video game distribution platforms, theoretical game theory, or online multiplayer games?

Based on the search results, here's information about "winning strategy":

## In Game Theory

A strategy is typically used to mean a complete algorithm for playing a game, telling a player what to do for every possible situation. A winning strategy, in this context, is a plan of action that guarantees victory for a player regardless of what their opponent does.

There cannot be a winning strategy for both players for the same game, for if there were, the two strategies could be played against each other, and the resulting outcome would then be a win for both players, which is impossible.

## Applications in Different Games

The concept of winning strategy applies to various games:

- **Positional Games**: For every positional game there are exactly three options: either the first player has a winning strategy, or the second player has a winning strategy, or both players have strategies to enforce a draw.

- **Chess**: Chess strategy is the aspect of chess play concerned with evaluation of chess positions and setting goals and long-term plans for future play, which involves taking into account factors such as the relative value of pieces on the board, pawn structure, king safety, and control of key squares.

- **Poker**: The fundamental theorem of poker states that every time you play your hand the way you would if you could see your opponents' cards, you gain, and this theorem is the foundation for many poker strategy topics.

Web search results for query: "Imperfect information game"

Links: [{"title":"Perfect information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_information"},{"title":"Complete information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_information"},{"title":"Incomplete information network game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_information_network_game"},{"title":"Bayesian game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_game"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Manipulated Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulated_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Extensive-form game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extensive-form_game"},{"title":"Information set (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_set_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Subgame perfect equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subgame_perfect_equilibrium"},{"title":"Information asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry"}]

Based on the search results, here's what imperfect information games are:

## Definition

An imperfect information game is played when the players do not know all moves already made by the opponent such as a simultaneous move game.

## Key Characteristics

Games where some aspect of play is hidden from opponents – such as the cards in poker and bridge – are examples of games with imperfect information. More formally, if a game has an information set with more than one member that game is said to have imperfect information.

## How It Affects Gameplay

In games with imperfect information—such as most card games like poker or bridge—information sets may contain multiple nodes, reflecting the player's uncertainty about the true state of the game. This uncertainty fundamentally changes how players must reason about optimal strategies.

## Examples

Common examples of imperfect information games include:
- Poker and bridge
- Poker has both moves of chance (the cards being dealt) and imperfect information (the cards secretly held by other players)

By contrast, chess is an example of a game with perfect information, as each player can see all the pieces on the board at all times.

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Distributed Games with a Central Decision Maker" and extracted all key technologies and methodologies. Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - This paper proposes novel concepts and algorithmic solutions for distributed games with a central decision maker.

**Triples Extracted (9 total):**

1. **Nondeterministic finite automaton** (uses) - The foundational automata model extended for distributed games
2. **Perfect information** (uses) - Contrasts with the partial-information games studied in the paper
3. **Safety property** (uses) - A key winning objective with efficient algorithmic solutions
4. **Parity game** (uses) - The parity objectives analyzed in the paper
5. **Finite-state machine** (proposes) - The paper formulates finite-state distributed strategies with optimal memory
6. **Game theory** (uses) - Theoretical foundation for strategic interactions
7. **Automata theory** (uses) - Framework for modeling non-deterministic asynchronous automata
8. **Distributed computing** (uses) - The domain where these games are played
9. **Strategy (game theory)** (proposes) - Novel constructions of distributed winning strategies

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms the output meets all requirements.
